title.value: Transnational conservation to anticipate future plant shifts in Europe
title.justification: The title "Transnational conservation to anticipate future plant shifts in Europe" accurately reflects the aims and scope of the study which focuses on developing conservation strategies in the European Alps to prepare for future biodiversity changes.
title.quote: Here we assess the robustness of the current European reserve network to safeguard the European Alps’ flora by 2080 using semi-mechanistic simulations.

extractions.description: This study explores strategies for designing a resilient conservation network in Europe by 2030, focusing on the European Alps. Using semi-mechanistic simulations, the paper evaluates the effectiveness of current protected areas and predicts future biodiversity shifts due to climate change and land-use alterations. The research emphasizes the importance of transnational efforts to maintain biodiversity across the Alps.

type.justification: The study uses empirical methods like semi-mechanistic simulations and species distribution models to predict and analyze conservation needs.
type.quote: Overall, our SDM approach showed very good performances, with an average true skill statistics and Boyce index of the kept models ranging between ~0.6 and ~0.8 across the 1,711 species considered.

name.justification: The paper's focus on biodiversity conservation, species distribution, and ecosystem management aligns with the research field of Ecology.
name.quote: Here we investigate the efficiency of the current European network, and of its potential transnational expansion, in protecting the plant multifaceted diversity and uniqueness of the European Alps...

name.justification: The study focuses on the spatial distribution of species and habitats across the European Alps, which is a fundamental aspect of geographical ecology.
name.quote: Spatial gains are shown in green, and spatial losses are shown in purple. Relative diversity represents the diversity expected under a given taxonomic diversity (Methods).

name.justification: Species Distribution Models are used in the paper to project future species range distributions and their shifts under climate change scenarios.
name.quote: Using an ensemble of species distribution models (SDMs) for 1,711 plant species at 100 m resolution, a high-coverage database of species traits and two mega-phylogenies, we predicted future changes in species distributional range.

is_contributed.justification: SDMs were used as a standard tool to project species distributions, not as a new model developed by the authors.
is_contributed.quote: Our SDM approach showed very good performances, with an average true skill statistics...

is_executed.justification: The SDMs were used to execute predictions and generate data for analysis within the study.
is_executed.quote: Using our model outputs (see ‘SDMs’ in Methods) and phylogenetic and functional information, we calculated the multifaceted diversity distribution of the European Alps...

is_compared.justification: There is no explicit mention of the SDMs being compared against other modeling techniques in the paper.
is_compared.quote: The paper focuses on applying SDMs, but there is no direct numerical comparison with other models.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not provide a specific referenced title for the Species Distribution Models utilized, as they are a generic modeling approach.

name.justification: GBIF is mentioned as a primary source of observational data used for species distribution modeling.
name.quote: The final observational dataset used in this study included (1) a compiled dataset from 75 various sources (~71%) and (2) a large compilation of observations extracted from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper mentions GBIF as a data source but does not cite a specific GBIF publication.
referenced_paper_title.quote: ...extracted from the Global Biodiversity Information Facility (GBIF; http://www.gbif.org/)...

name.justification: Zonation is used for conservation planning analysis within the study.
name.quote: For this, we used the additive benefit function (ABF) algorithm of the Zonation software (see ‘Zonation’ in Methods) with our species model outputs and their phylogenetic and functional information.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper does not provide a specific reference to a publication describing the Zonation software.
